definition: To slowly destroy or wear away by chemical action; to eat into.
examples: Salt air can corrode metal railings.
Acids corroded the old pipes.

definition: Scattered pieces of waste or remains.
examples: After the storm, debris covered the path.
Workers cleared building debris from the site.
She was elated to hear the good news.
The team felt elated after the win.

definition: To use something or someone unfairly or to the best advantage; a brave or daring deed (noun).
examples: The company was fined for exploiting workers. (verb)
Ancient myths tell of heroic exploits. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Exploit = use to the limit; exploits = notable deeds.

definition: Freedom to act within limits; extra time or space to allow for error.
examples: We have some leeway on the deadline.
Give yourself leeway when parking a trailer.

definition: Much smaller than usual; a small-scale copy.
examples: He built a miniature railway in the shed. (adjective)
The museum displayed a miniature of the castle. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Miniature = mini version of the real thing.

definition: Able to move or be moved easily; a phone (UK) or a hanging art piece that moves.
examples: The patient is mobile after surgery. (adjective)
Please switch off your mobile during the show. (noun, UK)

definition: The beginning or start of something, often something unpleasant.
examples: Warm clothes help at the onset of winter.
The onset of rain cleared the park.

definition: To flow or leak out slowly; a soft, wet mud or slime (noun).
examples: Sap oozed from the cut branch. (verb)
Their boots sank into the river ooze. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Ooze = slow and smooth like honey.

definition: Causing feelings of pity, especially because something is weak or poor.
examples: The abandoned shed looked pathetic in the rain.
It was a pathetic attempt to hide the mess.

definition: Done in preparation for something more important; an event that comes before the main event.
examples: We did preliminary tests on the samples. (adjective)
She won her preliminary and reached the final. (noun)

definition: A long search for something; to search for something.
examples: They set out on a quest for the lost city. (noun)
Scientists quest for clean energy solutions. (verb, formal/literary)

extra.memory_tip: Quest = question + test: a searching journey.

definition: To hold back from action; to keep under control.
examples: He restrained himself from shouting.
Barriers restrained the crowd.

definition: To save something from being lost or destroyed; the items saved.
examples: They salvaged books from the flooded room. (verb)
The salvage from the wreck was auctioned. (noun)

definition: To clean by rubbing hard; to search a place thoroughly; the act of scouring.
examples: Use a brush to scour the pan. (verb)
Volunteers scoured the beach for litter. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Scour = scrub or scour the area for clues.
